segment.source: Install digital certificates on Windows 10 Mobile (Windows 10)
segment.target: Install digital certificates on Windows 10 Mobile (Windows 10)

segment.source: Digital certificates bind the identity of a user or computer to a pair of keys that can be used to encrypt and sign digital information.
segment.target: Digital certificates bind the identity of a user or computer to a pair of keys that can be used to encrypt and sign digital information.

segment.source: Install digital certificates on Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Install digital certificates on Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Digital certificates bind the identity of a user or computer to a pair of keys that can be used to encrypt and sign digital information.
segment.target: Digital certificates bind the identity of a user or computer to a pair of keys that can be used to encrypt and sign digital information.

segment.source: Certificates are issued by a certification authority (CA) that vouches for the identity of the certificate holder, and they enable secure client communications with websites and services.
segment.target: Certificates are issued by a certification authority (CA) that vouches for the identity of the certificate holder, and they enable secure client communications with websites and services.

segment.source: Certificates in Windows 10 Mobile are primarily used for the following purposes:
segment.target: Certificates in Windows 10 Mobile are primarily used for the following purposes:

segment.source: To create a secure channel using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) between a phone and a web server or service.
segment.target: To create a secure channel using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) between a phone and a web server or service.

segment.source: To authenticate a user to a reverse proxy server that is used to enable Microsoft Exchange ActiveSync (EAS) for email.
segment.target: To authenticate a user to a reverse proxy server that is used to enable Microsoft Exchange ActiveSync (EAS) for email.

segment.source: For installation and licensing of applications (from the Windows Phone Store or a custom company distribution site).
segment.target: For installation and licensing of applications (from the Windows Phone Store or a custom company distribution site).

segment.source: Install certificates using Microsoft Edge
segment.target: Install certificates using Microsoft Edge

segment.source: A certificate can be posted on a website and made available to users through a device-accessible URL that they can use to download the certificate.
segment.target: A certificate can be posted on a website and made available to users through a device-accessible URL that they can use to download the certificate.

segment.source: When a user accesses the page and taps the certificate, it opens on the device.
segment.target: When a user accesses the page and taps the certificate, it opens on the device.

segment.source: The user can inspect the certificate, and if they choose to continue, the certificate is installed on the Windows 10 Mobile device.
segment.target: The user can inspect the certificate, and if they choose to continue, the certificate is installed on the Windows 10 Mobile device.

segment.source: Install certificates using email
segment.target: Install certificates using email

segment.source: The Windows 10 Mobile certificate installer supports .cer, .p7b, .pem, and .pfx files.
segment.target: The Windows 10 Mobile certificate installer supports .cer, .p7b, .pem, and .pfx files.

segment.source: To install certificates via email, make sure your mail filters do not block .cer files.
segment.target: To install certificates via email, make sure your mail filters do not block .cer files.

segment.source: Certificates that are sent via email appear as message attachments.
segment.target: Certificates that are sent via email appear as message attachments.

segment.source: When a certificate is received, a user can tap to review the contents and then tap to install the certificate.
segment.target: When a certificate is received, a user can tap to review the contents and then tap to install the certificate.

segment.source: Typically, when an identity certificate is installed, the user is prompted for the password (or passphrase) that protects it.
segment.target: Typically, when an identity certificate is installed, the user is prompted for the password (or passphrase) that protects it.

segment.source: Install certificates using mobile device management (MDM)
segment.target: Install certificates using mobile device management (MDM)

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile supports root, CA, and client certificate to be configured via MDM.
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile supports root, CA, and client certificate to be configured via MDM.

segment.source: Using MDM, an administrator can directly add, delete, or query root and CA certificates, and configure the device to enroll a client certificate with a certificate enrollment server that supports Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP).
segment.target: Using MDM, an administrator can directly add, delete, or query root and CA certificates, and configure the device to enroll a client certificate with a certificate enrollment server that supports Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP).

segment.source: SCEP enrolled client certificates are used by Wi-Fi, VPN, email, and browser for certificate-based client authentication.
segment.target: SCEP enrolled client certificates are used by Wi-Fi, VPN, email, and browser for certificate-based client authentication.

segment.source: An MDM server can also query and delete SCEP enrolled client certificate (including user installed certificates), or trigger a new enrollment request before the current certificate is expired.
segment.target: An MDM server can also query and delete SCEP enrolled client certificate (including user installed certificates), or trigger a new enrollment request before the current certificate is expired.

segment.source: Warning: Do not use SCEP for encryption certificates for S/MIME.
segment.target: Warning: Do not use SCEP for encryption certificates for S/MIME.

segment.source: You must use a PFX certificate profile to support S/MIME on Windows 10 Mobile.
segment.target: You must use a PFX certificate profile to support S/MIME on Windows 10 Mobile.

segment.source: For instructions on creating a PFX certificate profile in Microsoft Intune, see Enable access to company resources using certificate profiles with Microsoft Intune.
segment.target: For instructions on creating a PFX certificate profile in Microsoft Intune, see Enable access to company resources using certificate profiles with Microsoft Intune.

segment.source: Process of installing certificates using MDM
segment.target: Process of installing certificates using MDM

segment.source: The MDM server generates the initial cert enroll request including challenge password, SCEP server URL, and other enrollment related parameters.
segment.target: The MDM server generates the initial cert enroll request including challenge password, SCEP server URL, and other enrollment related parameters.

segment.source: The policy is converted to the OMA DM request and sent to the device.
segment.target: The policy is converted to the OMA DM request and sent to the device.

segment.source: The trusted CA certificate is installed directly during MDM request.
segment.target: The trusted CA certificate is installed directly during MDM request.

segment.source: The device accepts certificate enrollment request.
segment.target: The device accepts certificate enrollment request.

segment.source: The device generates private/public key pair.
segment.target: The device generates private/public key pair.

segment.source: The device connects to Internet-facing point exposed by MDM server.
segment.target: The device connects to Internet-facing point exposed by MDM server.

segment.source: MDM server creates a certificate that is signed with proper CA certificate and returns it to device.
segment.target: MDM server creates a certificate that is signed with proper CA certificate and returns it to device.

segment.source: Note: The device supports the pending function to allow server side to do additional verification before issuing the cert.
segment.target: Note: The device supports the pending function to allow server side to do additional verification before issuing the cert.

segment.source: In this case, a pending status is sent back to the device.
segment.target: In this case, a pending status is sent back to the device.

segment.source: The device will periodically contact the server, based on preconfigured retry count and retry period parameters.
segment.target: The device will periodically contact the server, based on preconfigured retry count and retry period parameters.

segment.source: Retrying ends when either: A certificate is successfully received from the server The server returns an error The number of retries reaches the preconfigured limit
segment.target: Retrying ends when either: A certificate is successfully received from the server The server returns an error The number of retries reaches the preconfigured limit

segment.source: The cert is installed in the device.
segment.target: The cert is installed in the device.

segment.source: Browser, Wi-Fi, VPN, email, and other first party applications have access to this certificate.
segment.target: Browser, Wi-Fi, VPN, email, and other first party applications have access to this certificate.

segment.source: Note: If MDM requested private key being stored in Trusted Process Module (TPM) (configured during enrollment request), the private key will be saved in TPM.
segment.target: Note: If MDM requested private key being stored in Trusted Process Module (TPM) (configured during enrollment request), the private key will be saved in TPM.

segment.source: Note that SCEP enrolled cert protected by TPM isn’t guarded by a PIN.
segment.target: Note that SCEP enrolled cert protected by TPM isn’t guarded by a PIN.

segment.source: However, if the certificate is imported to the Passport for Work Key Storage Provider (KSP), it is guarded by the Passport PIN.
segment.target: However, if the certificate is imported to the Passport for Work Key Storage Provider (KSP), it is guarded by the Passport PIN.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Configure S/MIME
segment.target: Configure S/MIME
